description.narrative: UNDP har ansökt om finansiering om 101 736 369 SEK för att genomföra "UNDP:s program för lokalt fredsbyggande 2016-2021". Det övergripande målet med programmet är att bidra till etableringen av en plattform som kan stödja implementeringen av FN:s globala mål - de globala målen för hållbar utveckling som är en del av Agenda 2030 för hållbar utveckling. Fokus är på mål 16 - fred, rättvisa och starka institutioner - för att kunna uppnå en minskning i ojämlikhet, och för att stärka lokala och nationella fredsinstitutioner och en minskning av den politiska polariseringen.

UNDP has applied to Sida for funding of 101 736 369 SEK, to carry out the “UNDP Program for local peace building 2016-2021”. The general objective of the Program is to contribute to the establishment of a country platform that promotes the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals -SDGs- in Colombia, with emphasis in SDG 16, in order to advance towards the reduction of inequalities, the strengthening of territorial peace institutions and the diminution of political polarization.

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

tag.narrative: 16.3 - Främja rättssäkerheten på nationell och internationell nivå samt säkerställa lika tillgång till rättvisa för alla.
16.3 - Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.
16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.

title.narrative: Signed Agreement UNDP- Sweden Local Peacebuilding Program 2016-2021
Signed Decision on Agreement UNDP - Sweden Local Peacebuilding Program
Signed Decision on II Agreement Amendment
Signed Decision on III Agreement Amendment
Signed Decision on IV Agreement Amendment

description.narrative: The main result of the program in 2019 was the consolidation of multi-stakeholder platforms for peace and development at the national and local levels with participation of public authorities, civil society organizations (CSO) and the private sector. Results are found along the program’s three strategic lines: 1. Institutional set-up for peacebuilding and development; 2. Dialogue and participation for public policy formulation and the achievement of Agenda 2030; 3 Coexistence, reconciliation and reintegration. Line 1. Institutional set-up for peacebuilding and development The program offered support to 30 multi-stakeholder coordination platforms in nine departments, covering diverse topics as the local implementation of SDG 16, reintegration of former combatants, local peacebuilding, promotion of human rights, Development Plans with a Territorial Focus (PDETs by their Spanish acronym), gender-based violence prevention and democracy. UNDP has become a key partner for facilitating the implementation of sections of the Peace Agreement prioritized by the National Government, such as the implementation of the Action Plans for Territorial Transformation (PATR by their Spanish acronym) of PDETs and the operation of Local Peace Councils. UNDP assisted 48 subnational institutions through its local offices, to adopt strategies for achieving SGDs and improving public service delivery. As concrete examples, two indigenous reservations in Meta were supported to improve its local governance by formulating “Comprehensive Life Plans” for the communities; also, local governments were assisted to formulate and implement policies on disabilities, youth, environmental sustainability and climate change. The program contributed to strengthen key public institutions for the guarantee of Human Rights at the local and national levels: the national Ombudsman Office, municipal Ombudsman Offices (Personerías municipales) and Mesa Nacional de Garantías (MNG), a dialogue platform on Huma Rights for public authorities, civil society and the international community. UNDP’s work as technical secretariat of MNG enabled collective analyses of measures undertaken by the Government to address attacks to community leaders and Human Rights defenders, as well as providing inputs for the formulation of a national policy on the topic. Line 2. Dialogue and participation for public policy formulation and the achievement of Agenda 2030 The second strategic line aims at strengthening civil society’s participation and engagement in public decision-making for sustainable development. UNDP reported that the program has contributed to increase 2.456 local stakeholders’ capacities for social dialogue, conflict prevention and reaching community-based agreements, out of which 367 were indigenous people and 765 were women and young people. Local UNDP’s offices in five departments worked with women’s organizations to develop their capacities for political participation, advocacy and overseeing public management with a gender perspective. Furthermore, through a partnership with the Ombudsman Office, 2.461 female leaders received training in peacebuilding and conflict transformations. The program also supported local strategies for environmental protection in departments like Caquetá, were six governors signed the Amazonian Pact for the protection of forests and climate change adaptation in the Amazon region, and Antioquia, where management plans for protected areas were formulated involving eight environmental conflicts. During 2019, the program fostered social dialogue around the implementation of the SDGs by strengthening the national multi-stakeholder platform managed by the National Planification Department (DNP by its Spanish acronym) with technical staff, supporting the operation of the virtual platform to systematize information on the SDGs and the development of the SDG Corporate Tracker. In addition, a second call for innovation initiatives of civil society that contribute to achieving SDGs was conducted, resulting in seven initiatives selected to receive small grants in areas like water management, sanitation, sustainable rural production and education. Line 3. Coexistence, reconciliation and reintegration In this strategic line, the Program continued to provide technical and financial support to four national civil society organizations (Fundación PARES, Fundación Vive Bailando, Movilizatorio and Recon) to promote civic participation, Human Rights protection, social innovation and entrepreneurship. These initiatives were implemented in various conflict-affected regions and impacted more than 1.300 people, mainly young people. Accompanying the reintegration of former FARC combatants, the program strengthened the gender and community reintegration component through seven productive initiatives that benefited 115 women and 35 men in former Territorial Areas for Training and Reintegration (ETCR by their Spanish acronym). In addition, 150 women were accompanied in quick impact projects for income generation and interventions were conducted to improve care spaces within former ETCR to promote gender equality. UNDP’s local offices have also facilitated processes in the Departmental Reincorporation Boards, helping to build trust between the parties. The operation of local UNDP’s offices, partially financed by the program, has contributed to articulating United Nations System’s response and strengthening the triple nexus, through their leadership of Local Coordination Teams in various departments.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
